intro: Plagiobothrys humifusus, commonly known as the lowland sand verbena, is a flowering plant native to the western United States. It is a perennial herb that typically grows in sandy or gravelly soils, often in arid or semi-arid environments. The plant produces small, clustered flowers that are usually pink or purple in color, which bloom during the spring and early summer. Its leaves are generally linear and may have a slight hairy texture, contributing to its adaptability in dry conditions. Plagiobothrys humifusus is part of the Boraginaceae family and is known for its ecological importance in supporting local pollinators.
